block.p: Barak's Coalition Erodes On Eve of Peace Talks Prime Minister Ehud Barak's government disintegrated, as one right-leaning party after another quit in protest of anticipated concessions to the Palestinians, leaving him on unsteady ground on the eve of his departure to a summit meeting.

World AIDS Forum Opens South Africa's president, Thabo Mbeki, opening the first international conference on AIDS in a developing country, singled out poverty, rather than the disease ravaging his country and continent, as Africa's leading killer. He did not address his earlier questions about the cause and treatment of AIDS.

Test Failure May Delay Decision Senior advisers to President Clinton said they expect him to make a decision this summer on whether to proceed with a missile defense system, but they acknowledged that the failure of a test on Saturday made it far more likely that Mr. Clinton's successor would ultimately decide the project's fate.
Deadly Bombs Near Chechnya One week after Chechen rebels killed 33 Russian soldiers in a wave of bomb attacks, two smaller bombs killed seven civilians in Russian areas close to Chechnya.

Ulster March Turns Violent A demonstration by a traditional Protestant organization over a ban on the group's marching route through a Roman Catholic neighborhood was marred by violent protests and clashes with soldiers.
Pope Critical of Gay Event Pope John Paul II expressed ''bitterness'' about a gay pride festival held in Rome during this Roman Catholic Holy Year, saying that the event was an affront to the church.

Kosovo Pact Is Threatened The first agreement between the Serbs and the United Nations administration in Kosovo may provide better protection for the Serbian minority, but it threatens to unravel key Albanian participation in efforts to build a democratic Kosovo.

Peace Agreement in Fiji Rebels and the military signed an accord in Fiji to try to end a seven-week political crisis and to pave the way for the release of Prime Minister Mahendra Chaudhry and 26 other people held hostage by the rebels. The accord is to lead to the release of the hostages on Thursday.

Runoff Vote in Haiti A handful of Haitian voters, in a runoff election shunned by opposition candidates and international observers, cast their ballots for the few legislative and local offices that were not already won by the political party of former President Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
Alarm at Arrest in Egypt The recent arrest of a prominent sociologist on suspicion of ''defaming'' Egypt has alarmed human rights advocates around the region.

Parties Still Split Over Size of Tax Cut With projections of the federal budget surplus rising and both parties in full election-year mode, the debate over tax cuts is shifting from whether to what kinds. Republicans continue to press for bigger reductions than most Democrats will support, and there is unlikely to be any legislative breakthrough this year.

Hate Symbol at Work Employment experts say that the symbolic use of hangman's nooses, although still rare, is increasingly turning up in ordinary workplaces. And the nooses are affecting not just black employees, but also those of Asian, Hispanic and Native American descent. Officials at the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission say they have at least 20 noose-related lawsuits pending or recently resolved.

N.A.A.C.P. Convention Starts The chairman of the N.A.A.C.P. urged delegates to the group's convention to use their voting franchise in November, saying one more conservative vote on the Supreme Court could bring a setback for civil rights advocacy. The speech served as the official start of the N.A.A.C.P.'s 91st annual convention.

Secret Work at Lab Is Halted Classified work at the federal government's Pacific Northwest National Laboratory has been suspended as a result of a security lapse, according to Energy Department and laboratory officials. Laboratory officials suspended all classified work at the installation in Richland, Wash., after an employee discovered a classified document had been left in an unclassified but locked office for about a day.

Alliance for Fishing Quotas Fishermen and conservation groups are seeking to end the scramble and the dangers associated with the so-called derby approach to fishing, in which captains are given a strict limit of fish to compete for and a brief time to catch them. Those unhappy with this system would instead allot fishermen individual quotas.

Alzheimer's Increasing Rapidly Alzheimer's disease is increasing so fast that more than 22 million people worldwide will be affected by 2025, experts said. The experts urged new research to spot the earliest symptoms -- subtle ones that can emerge a decade before dementia strikes -- and hunt for ways to protect these people's brains.

DaimlerChrysler Plans Offices at Chrysler Building DaimlerChrysler A.G. said that it hoped to lease part of the Chrysler Building in Manhattan as a ''virtual headquarters'' -- a meeting place for its board and a center for its investor and public relations staffs. The move would reaffirm the company's American roots and put its image makers into the media capital of the world and near Wall Street.

Woman Attacked on Street A 25-year-old woman walking from church to a subway station suffered a fractured skull when she was struck from behind by a man wielding a melon-sized chunk of concrete, the authorities said.

2 Dead in Van Accident A student and a teacher from a Roman Catholic high school on Long Island were killed in an accident on a class trip in Arizona when their van ran off a highway about 40 miles south of the Grand Canyon, the police said.

Giuliani in Accident A driver swerved in front of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's sport-utility vehicle on the Grand Central Parkway, causing a three-car pileup that injured three police detectives -- but not Mr. Giuliani -- before the driver sped away, city officials said.
2nd Victim Dies After Fire A man injured in a three-alarm fire that ravaged an East Side apartment on Saturday night has died, the second person killed in the blaze, the police said.

Hillary Clinton on Tour Hillary Rodham Clinton, in the fourth day of her Senate campaign tour through western New York, renewed her call for the Federal Trade Commission to broaden its investigation of sharply increased gasoline prices.
Harry Potter Sets Records ''Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire,'' the latest book in J. K. Rowling's wildly popular series about a boy wizard, set records in its first weekend of sales.
Sampras Takes Wimbledon Pete Sampras beat Patrick Rafter, 6-7 (10), 7-6 (5), 6-4, 6-2, to win his seventh Wimbledon title.

Harold Sack The nation's pre-eminent dealer in American period furniture, who paid a staggering $12.1 million for an 18th-century Newport desk-bookcase in 1989, he was 89. The price of the desk was then the highest ever at auction for an object other than a painting.
James C. Quayle A newspaper publisher from Indiana and the father of former Vice President Dan Quayle, he was 79.

'Big Brother' Ratings Falter CBS's ''Big Brother,'' the latest effort in the reality television trend, is falling far short of the phenomenon status reached by two other European imports, ABC's ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' and CBS's ''Survivor.'' It runs the risk of becoming a hugely expensive flop.
Heinz to Sell Green Ketchup H.J. Heinz plans to introduce a version of its ketchup today that will be bright green and is intended to appeal to children -- but has no taste difference.

Offer for Nissan Affiliate Johnson Controls, the auto parts manufacturer, will begin a tender offer today for the shares of the Ikeda Bussan Company, a Nissan Motor Company affiliate that is best known for making premium-quality car seats.

PeopleSoft Bets on Future PeopleSoft plans to show the latest version of its ''enterprise software'' at a news conference on Tuesday. Investors, clients and competitors are wondering whether the software, a huge and complex program that companies use to automate dozens of tasks, like managing customer relations and human resources, will lead to the demise or revival of the once high-flying company.

Satellite Radio Financing XM Satellite Radio is expected to announce today that it has completed its planned financing, raising the last $235 million from a group of investors, in a sign that long-promised satellite radio broadcasting is coming closer to fruition.

Invitrogen to Buy Dexter The Invitrogen Corporation, which develops medical kits for genetic research, has agreed to buy the Dexter Corporation, a chemical maker, and the biological-products maker Life Technologies Inc. for $1.9 billion in cash and stock.
